results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace and companions tour ‘Ayers Rock’ (Uluru) as it was then named, and ‘The Olgas’ (Kata Tjuta), and he provides some context for both sites, Indigenous names and the connection to local Indigenous Australians.

In acknowledging the importance of Uluru to Indigenous Australians Wallace provides a respectful and admiring narrative. However, information and context of the 1960s is unlikely to be as accurate or as sensitive as a narrative prepared with or by current traditional owners. (In 1985 the Australian Government returned Uluru-Kata Tjuta National Park to the traditional owners of the area – the Anangu).

Originally made on Super 8mm film, with a sound track and voiceover narrative.

00:00:02:00 title card ‘Land of the Pitjandjara’ (Pitjantjatjara)
00:00:42:00 we see Mount Conner, as stated by the voiceover
00:01:10:00 a large pelican in the sandy landscape and voiceover explaining ‘Curtin Springs is one of the great cattle stations of the (red) centre’, and travellers stand around a well packed ‘Land Rover’ off-road motor car
00:01:30:00 filming from the car along a muddy track
00:01:40:00 travellers from buses gather wood for campfires as the narrator explains their destination is ‘Ayers Rock (Uluru)’, followed by stacking dead mulga branches ‘atop the vehicles’
00:02:00:00 driving under stone entry gate and ironwork sign ‘Ayers Rock and Mount Olga’
00:02:19:00 approaching Uluru
00:02:38:00 a ‘Tjintir-tjintirpa’ (willy wagtail) pecking at dry scrub grass while Wallace’s narration gives a brief description of the connection of local Indigenous Australians, the Indigenous name ‘Uluru’ and context in which it sits, the ‘dreamtime’ legends
00:03:28:00 views of the northern, or as Wallace points out, ‘the sunny side of the Rock’
00:04:00:00 views around the base of Uluru and Wallace continues his narrative
00:04:20:00 a long shallow cave
00:04:30:00 ‘The Olgas’ (Kata Tjuta) on the horizon a short distance away from Uluru
00:04:43:00 close-up of ‘the Kangaroo Tail’, a long detached piece of rock stretching across Uluru
00:05:08:00 a ‘wet weather cave’ that Wallace describes as ‘especially significant’ that contains Indigenous rock art. Wallace explains that this art depicts ‘totemic symbols’, which are ‘attributed to the dreamtime heroes’ and only a ‘chosen few of the tribe’ can work on the artworks for conservation. The soundtrack changes to include some traditional singing.
00:05:53:00 close-ups of beautiful rock formations at the base of Uluru
00:06:28:00 the travellers climbing on ‘the western end’ according to Wallace’s narrative
00:07:00:00 a dingo approaches the camera
00:07:24:00 filming from a vehicle approaching Kata Tjuta; the road is flooded or as Wallace narrates, more like ‘a canal’ than a road, needing a ‘good deal of reconnaissance’
00:08:13:00 dramatic footage of the vehicles driving through the muddy water covering the road
00:08:56:00 sunrise filmed as it lights up the eastern side of Kata Tjuta, which Wallace describes in very artistic terms
00:09:15:00 the travellers have breakfast at their campsite
00:09:30:00 views of the ‘Walpa Gorge Walk’ and difficult spots for walking or climbing
00:10:08:00 the travellers drinking directly from Walpa Creek by lying down
00:10:51:00 the travellers sit for lunch between the giant ‘tors’ (isolated weathered rocks) which make up Kata Tjuta, on the other side of the Walpa Gorge
00:11:12:10 various views around as the travellers walk ‘into the heart of the Olgas’
00:12:40:00 ‘gazing out across the expansive desert’ to the ‘Petermann Ranges’
00:13:06:00 birds, insects and a goanna as well as more views of the monolith rocks along the way back to the campsite
00:14:19:00 small tents at the campsite and views back to Kata Tjuta
00:14:56:00 title card ‘The End’ features a silhouette of an Indigenous Australian man and spear sitting on a rock looking out over the land

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part one of two and is titled ‘Festival City’. Wallace and companions travel by car to Adelaide in South Australia, filming the trip as they go.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Festival City’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:02:18:00 ‘Waterfalls Gully’ enroute to Adelaide
00:03:15:00 women posing with their cameras for the filmmaker’s camera.
00:03:39:00 women standing in front of a rock walk before climbing.
00:04:49:00 Adelaide Arts Centre.
00:05:16:00 paddle boats and fountain on the Torrens River in Adelaide.
00:06:31:00 churches in Adelaide.
00:07:09:00 camping alongside a pop-up van.
00:08:06:00 looking at an outdoor art exhibition.
00:09:42:00 sheep in a paddock.
00:10:03:00 historic ‘Peerless Roller Mills’ building in ‘Birdwood’, South Australia.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:09:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Orchid Isle’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:23:00 boats and yachts in small harbour.
00:01:36:00 Fijian musicians wearing elaborate floral costumes performing in an outdoor setting.
00:02:10:00 Fijian style thatched houses.
00:03:01:00 turtle swimming.
00:04:55:00 tourists participating in cultural performance.
00:05:35:00 palm weaving being shown to tourists.
00:06:51:00 passengers onboard a ferry listening to local musicians.
00:09:43:00 large ship at port in Suva.
00:10:18:00 local traffic in Suva.
00:10:30:00 marching military band in Suva.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.

Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Fascinating Fiji’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 drive through a plantation
00:01:05:00 buffalo
00:01:31:00 sign for the Raki Raki Hotel.
00:03:44:00 seaside township
00:04:10:00 foraging on the foreshore.
00:04:40:00 sign ‘Welcome to Nausori’ before crossing the (old) Rewa bridge by car.
00:04:56:00 ‘Nausori Municipal Market’ on the island of ‘Viti Levu’ showing various vegetable stalls and some produce boxes from New Zealand.
00:05:45:00 sign for ‘Kings Road’ showing miles to various destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.destinations
00:06:16:00 woman paddling a slim canoe on water before small boys in a boat.
00:10:14:00 football game
00:11:10:00 one of Wallace’s travelling companions holds a tourist pose for the camera.

The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.title: The Dam builders
results.creator_credit: Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works and Cine Service
results.brief_description: Gives a brief history of the Melbourne water supply system and the efforts of the MMBW to create enjoyable environments such as landscaping and recreation facilities in several catchment areas. Highlights the construction of the Cardinia Reservoir, near Emerald, now the largest storage area for Melbourne.

results.title: Our fragile coast: The Coast, a question of balance
results.creator_credit: David Hughes and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: The first half of this compilation tape focuses on erosion and deposition at Port Campbell, the Gippsland Lakes and Port Phillip, to be used in conjunction with the Earth in Action topic of the Year 12 Geography course; the second shows how competing human interests could destroy the coastal ecology.

results.title: Fatness, foods, fads (compilation)
results.brief_description: Fatness, foods and fads outlines the 5 food groups and examines the fallacies of diets such as the Israeli army diet, the no carbohydrate diet, the grapefruit diet and the macrobiotic diet. 2. “Energy, food and exercise” shows how to achieve a proper balance of food and exercise for particular needs. 3.”Whats cooking” highlights the health problems that abound in the unhygienic kitchen and poses solutions. Compared by Andrew Daddo.

results.title: A Real man's job: Images of Australian women in wartime [kit]
results.creator_credit: Felicity Cockram, ImMEDIAte Action, Australian War Memorial and History Teacher's Association of Victoria
results.brief_description: Subtitled Images of Australian women in wartime this kit aims to identify the real contribution that women made during both world wars and also at the images of women in wartime that were projected. Authored by Tim Gurry, Robert Lewis and Richard Reid, the kit draws together a wide variety of material with suggestions for its use, into nine Evidence Files, a videocassette and Teacher’s notes.

results.title: Fair go!
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Victorian Trades Hall Council
results.brief_description: Fair go! is a step towards meeting the needs of young people for information about their rights as workers. Using a fresh, entertaining presentation, the program follows the experiences of school-leavers Kelly and Sam, as they fall unawares into a series of near disasters in new jobs.
